column16: What is your annual household income?
column17: What was your overall impression of this event (quality, lighting, sound, value)?
column18: Please share any other suggestions or ideas that would help us enhance your experience at Gesa Power House Theatre. If you would like someone to respond to your feedback, please include your contact information. Thank you!

column17: I couldn’t hear some of what he said

column18: Try to bring Mike Wiley back for one of his other plays!!!

column17: Great performer. Bring him back for another of his plays, then he’ll gain traction in the community. I went because my granddaughter s@w him through his school performance. Next year it would be a new group of kids. And more families might come. Give family discounts. A great way to teach history.
The performer interacted superbly with the audience and was especially respectful and attentive towards questions from children.
column18: Be more attentive to sound system functions and keeping any visual aids tuned in to what the performer is doing.
I wish more people had come to the play.

column17: Delightful small venue.  Felt like we were a small part of Mike Wiley’s recounting of 19th century life and struggles for freedom.

Sound was too low in the beginning but then fixed. The overall production was engaging, thought provoking and well done. Kudos to Mr Wiley for being able to bring the subject matter alive and for using the audience so effectively. Also great Q&A afterwards. I wish the audience had been larger!
column18: Awesome greeters and all volunteers make attendees feel welcome. Love this venue!

column17: Excellent!  Thoroughly enjoyed the performance and was glad to see an audience of all ages!  (I appreciated the opportunity to meet Michael after the performance - he's charming!)

Mike Wylie was very engaging. His genuine joy in interacting with the audience was unsurpassed. Regardless of the small audience size, he entertained, engaged, and performed with the greatest interests. Sound was an issue for both the announcer and actor as was conversation during the performance. It sounded like one of the entry doors was left open and what was meant to be a private conversation was now public. A friend had heard about his performance from a grade school grandchild who was impressed with his message and performance. The children, whom he selected to interact on stage were delighted to be chosen. His Q & A after was engaging and encouraged those free thinking artisans in the audience to continue to see this gift as valuable, as he relayed his interest in people watching and mimicing voices/body language as a child, which led to his performance career.  We are glad to hear that he will be returning next year.
column18: Perhaps complimentary tickets at the school performances, which would be coordinated through school office personnel would be another incentive for families to attend.

column17: Fantastic Show. I was laughing and crying. A great talent, an amazing story and yet another perspective on the dangers and sorrows of slavery. Thank you for bringing this show to WW.

The production was educational, inspiring, gripping, fun and sorrowful - what a story.  It was high-quality, lighting and sound was good - I didn't even know that the mic was off - the sound in the theater is great.  The House did a great job.  I look forward to his return for another production.
column18:
This is the time that I went to the bathroom after the performance and when I got to the lobby it was just a few people left.  I don't know what can be done to keep people to chat afterwards.  Perhaps it was such an uncomfortable topic that some felt they needed to go to their comfort zone.
LOVED the evening!
